answers.explanation: The Net Interest Margin (NIM) of SCBs remained robust at 3.6 per cent in March 2024, having moderated from its peak of 3.9 per cent in Q1 of FY24. (page 94-95)

The 56th GST Council approved major reforms including a 2-rate structure (18% standard, 5% merit), reduction of GST on cement from 28% to 18%, and exemption of GST on all individual life and health insurance policies. The special de-merit rate was proposed at 40%, not 30%, making statement IV incorrect.

Buoyed by a well-balanced inflation-growth dynamics, the MPC unanimously decided in its October 2024 meeting to change the policy stance from withdrawal of accommodation to neutral to provide it the flexibility to monitor the progress of ongoing disinflation. (Page 114)
According to a press release from July 2025, the Atal Pension Yojana (APY) has achieved a significant milestone by surpassing 8 crore total gross enrolments since its launch on May 9, 2015.
Under the 'Namo Drone Didi' scheme, Central Financial Assistance (CFA) is provided at the rate of 80% of the cost of the drone package, up to a maximum of Rs. 8.00 lakhs, to the selected women SHGs.

The document states on page 8 that 'Net FDI inflows, however, moderated during this period due to higher repatriations and outward investment, which is a sign of a mature market where foreign investors can enter and exit smoothly, reflecting positively on the Indian economy.' This indicates that the moderation was not due to negative sentiment but rather a characteristic of a maturing market. (Page 8)

Page 93, paragraph 2.23 of the Economic Survey 2023-24 states, 'The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of SCBs continued its downward trend, reaching a 12-year low of 2.8 per cent at the end of March 2024 from its peak of 11.2 per cent in FY18.' This is also supported by Chart II.7a on page 94.

The newly inserted section 194T mandates that a firm responsible for paying any sum like salary, remuneration, commission, bonus, or interest to a partner shall deduct income-tax at the rate of ten per cent. (Page 73)
The Government of India launched the PM Vishwakarma scheme in November 2024 with a total financial allocation of ₹13,000 crore to uplift traditional artisans and craftspeople.

The National Monetisation Pipeline (NMP) listed assets with a potential of ₹6 lakh crore for monetisation over FY22–FY25. During the period FY22-FY24, receipts worth ₹3.9 lakh crore have been recorded against a target of ₹4.3 lakh crore. (page 66)
For Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) stood at 16.8 per cent in March 2024, indicating strong capital buffers. (Page 18)
The RBI, in its February 2025 policy review, hiked the repo rate by 25 basis points as a measure to control rising inflation, taking the new policy rate to 6.75%.
According to the performance indicators of SCBs, the CRAR stood at a record high of 17.3 per cent as of March 2025, up from 16.8 per cent in March 2024. (Page 55, Chart 1.44)

Net FDI declined significantly to US$ 0.5 billion during April-November 2024, a sharp drop from the US$ 8.5 billion recorded in the same period a year ago. This was due to a rise in repatriation and net outward FDI. (Page 43)
In February 2025, the IRDAI implemented a significant policy change by increasing the FDI limit in the Indian insurance sector from the previous 49% to a new ceiling of 74%.

For 2025-26, structural model estimates indicate real GDP growth with Q1 at 7.3 per cent, Q2 at 7.2 per cent, and Q3 and Q4 both at 7.0 per cent. This shows the growth rate is expected to start at its highest and then moderate through the year.

The stress test results reveal that under 'adverse scenario 1', the aggregate CRAR of SCBs may deplete to 14.3 per cent, and four banks may breach the minimum capital requirement of 9 per cent by March 2026. (Page 90)
The COP29 climate summit took place in Baku, the capital city of Azerbaijan, in November 2024, where global climate change policies were discussed.

As per the amendment to section 194G, the words 'five per cent.' have been substituted with 'two per cent.' for TDS on commission on the sale of lottery tickets, effective from October 1, 2024. (Page 72, 199)
The Padma Vibhushan awards for 2025 were conferred upon Vyjayanthimala Bali, Koneru Ramakrishna Rao, and Dilip Sanghvi.

While the GNPA ratio of all SCBs is projected to improve to 2.5 per cent by March 2025 under the baseline scenario, it may rise to 3.4 per cent if the macroeconomic environment worsens to a severe stress scenario. (Page 86)
The PM Vishwakarma programme was launched in September 2023 to provide end-to-end support for traditional artisans and craftspeople working with traditional tools across 18 trades. (page 314)

A new proviso in section 80CCD(1B) allows a deduction for payment or deposit made to a minor's account under the pension scheme, subject to the condition that the aggregate amount of deduction shall not exceed fifty thousand rupees. (Page 42, 148)

Section 194LBC has been amended to provide a reduced uniform TDS rate of 10% on income in respect of investment in a securitisation trust, replacing the previous differential rates of 25% and 30%. (Page 57, 168)

The press release on the Nationwide Financial Inclusion Saturation Campaign states that it resulted in more than 2.6 crore fresh enrollments under the three Jan Suraksha social security schemes (PMJJBY, PMSBY, and APY) combined, not just under the Atal Pension Yojana (APY) alone. All other statements are correct as per their respective press releases.

The 'State of the Economy' article mentions that as of March 31, 2024, scheduled commercial banks' (SCBs') credit limits for the non-conventional energy sector stood at ₹1.19 lakh crore with a total outstanding of ₹75,251 crore. (Page 81)

The newly inserted section 44BBD(1) specifies that a sum equal to twenty-five per cent of the aggregate amounts (paid, payable, received, or deemed to be received) shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of the non-resident's business. (Page 39)

In the speech titled 'Transforming Grievance Redress: The AI Advantage', it is mentioned that nearly 57 per cent of the maintainable complaints in 2023-24 required mediation or formal intervention by the RBI Ombudsmen. (Page 8)

Liquidity conditions tightened during 2023-24. The average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) moderated to ₹485 crore during 2023-24 from ₹1.87 lakh crore in the previous year. (Page 29, para I.14)

The notes on Clause 3, which amends Section 2(42A), explicitly state at the end, 'This amendment will take effect retrospectively from 23rd July, 2024.' This makes the new 24-month rule applicable from this specific date. (Page 162)
